awd_abstract_narration:
Empowering informatics Diversity Enhanced Workforce (EiDEW) is a multi-institutional project proposed by the Indiana University (IU) School of Informatics and Computing (SoIC) at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis (IUPUI) and Ivy Tech Community College (Ivy Tech) in Indianapolis. The project seeks to increase the quality and quantity of information technology (IT) professionals - especially economically disadvantaged, academically talented underrepresented minorities -  who graduate from college. The EiDEW Scholar program will not only recruit, provide scholarship support to, and educate 80 associate and 60 baccalaureate students, but also create a rich framework of coherent interventions to ensure student persistence in STEM. Typical interventions planned include mentoring, internships and other types of support from freshman year through degree completion.  Close to graduation, EiDEW will partner with employers such as Microsoft to facilitate student career placement in the STEM workforce. 

Student recruitment will be facilitated by leveraging previously established connections with high schools. In previous NSF-funded research, IUPUI had success with the residential learning community model and cohort-based mentoring. These will be adapted and used in the EiDEW project. The informatics curriculum is based on active learning pedagogies with both Microsoft and CISCO providing various professional certification training during the summer. The project will potentially generate systematic knowledge regarding the value of combining co-curricular activities with provision of scholarship support for talented but financially needy college students. The consortium arrangement between Ivy Tech and IUPUI will provide a national model for two-year to four-year college transition in the S-STEM context.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of the EiDEW (LiFT) project were:

1) Graduate and place 80 IT associate and 60 IT baccalaureate degree economically disadvantaged and underrepresented minority (ED-URM) graduates into the informatics/computing workforce after the S-STEM funding in 2021; 2) Achieve a 90% success rate in degree completion and career placement among EiDEW Scholars; 3) Generate new knowledge on applying tailored curriculum and co-curricular activities that enhance ED-URM student recruitment, retention, achievement, persistence to graduation, and job placement; and, 4) Achieve EiDEW Scholar baccalaureate degree graduates with lower student loan indebtedness and greater preparation for graduate degree education.

The EiDEW project achieved major achievements as follows:

1) The project supported 108 IT associates and 102 baccalaureates to pursue IT-related degrees; 2) Achieved a 90% success rate in internship/job placements and degree completion, with 123 scholars successfully graduating; 3) The program sustained high retention rates, averaging 80.8% of LiFT scholars, surpassing Non-LiFT students' retention rates at the institution; and, 4) The average loan debt for S-STEM Bachelor's degree recipients was reduced to $5,963, while Non-S-STEM students had an average loan debt of $14,347.

The EiDEW/LiFT scholarship program was piloted in 2017 and continued for seven years until 2023. The seventh year of the program application was 2022-2023. During this time, 108 (66 IUPUI, 42 Ivy Tech Transfer) IUPUI students and 102 Ivy Tech students pursued their bachelor's, 4+1 master's, and associate's degrees in informatics, computer science, software development, server administration, and cybersecurity. As of December 2022, 123 scholars had graduated from IUPUI and Ivy Tech community colleges.

During the seven years of the LiFT Scholars Program, students could benefit from various program components, including orientation sessions, community-building and social events, and career readiness activities such as industry events and guest speakers. These activities were instrumental in helping the scholars establish their professional network with IT experts. Initially, the program orientation was designed to provide scholars with an overview of the program and to set clear expectations and responsibilities for all scholars. It also served as an opportunity to foster a sense of community among the incoming students. As the number of LiFT scholars increased over time, the program also expanded its co-curricular activities.

A total of 98 social events, including 71 industry events, 13 LiFT socials, and 14 end-of-semester celebrations, were organized by the LiFT program from the 2017 through 2023 academic year. These social events and career readiness activities aimed to foster the scholars' sense of belonging to the LiFT Scholars Program and their connections with industry professionals. Social activities, such as informal lunch socials, game nights, and end-of-semester celebrations, were organized every academic semester.

The LiFT Advisory Council members provided guidance and support to make the LiFT industry visits and speakers a reality. These experiences allowed students to compare and contrast work in the IT industry in both public and private settings and within companies of varying sizes. Periodically, the PI and the Program Manager for the LiFT Scholars Program attended and presented at various Conferences, providing an opportunity to network with other higher education administrators committed to supporting the retention and persistence of all students, especially the ED-URM populations. These connections provide a strong foundation for future knowledge generation by learning from best practices in assessment and persistence interventions. Significant outcomes of this work were published in the Journal for STEM Education Research entitled "The Importance of STEM Sense of Belonging and Academic Hope in Enhancing Persistence for Low-Income, Underrepresented STEM Students", Hansen et. al., (https://doi.org/10.1007/s41979-023-00096-8 or as a PDF here https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/s41979-023-00096-8.pdf.)

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2023
Modified by: Mathew J Palakal
